Chapter 12, Part 3: The Bodhisattva MahÄkÄÅ›yapa
Good sons!
Such disputes are the Buddha's realm, not something known by Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas.
If a person gives rise to doubt about this, it is still able to destroy immeasurable afflictions like Mount Sumeru. If one gives rise to certainty about this, it is called attachment.
Bodhisattva MahÄkÄÅ›yapa addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
What is meant by attachment?
The Buddha said:
Good sons!
Such a person, whether hearing from others, investigating the sÅ«tras themselves, or being deliberately taught by others, is unable to let go of the attached matter. This is called attachment.
KÄÅ›yapa said again:
World-Honored One!
Is such attachment good or not good?
Good sons!
Such attachment is not called good.
Why is it so?
Because it cannot destroy the net of doubts.
KÄÅ›yapa said again:
World-Honored One!
Such a person has never doubted from the beginning. How can it be said that he does not destroy the net of doubts?
Good man!
One who does not doubt is precisely doubting.
World-Honored One!
If someone says that a stream-enterer does not fall into the three evil destinies, can this person also be called attached and doubting?
Good man!
This can be called definite, but it cannot be called doubting.
Why is it so?
Good man!
For example, if a person first sees a person and a tree, and later while walking at night, he sees a stump from afar, he will give rise to a doubtful thought, wondering if it is a person or a tree.
Good man!

If a person first sees a bhiká¹£u and a brahman, and later while on the road, he sees a bhiká¹£u from afar, he will immediately give rise to a doubtful thought, wondering if it is a Å›ramaá¹‡a or a brahman.
Good man!
It is like a person who first sees an ox and a water buffalo, and later from a distance sees an ox, and then gives rise to a doubtful thought, Is that an ox?
Or is it a water buffalo?
Good man!
All sentient beings first see two things, and then give rise to doubt.
Why is this?
Because the mind is unclear.
I also do not say that a stream-enterer will fall into the three evil destinies or not fall into the three evil destinies. Why would this person give rise to a doubtful mind?
KÄÅ›yapa said:
World-Honored One!
As the Buddha has said, one must first see something before one can doubt it.
There are people who, when they have not yet seen two kinds of things, also give rise to doubt.
What are they?
Namely, nirvÄá¹‡a.
World-Honored One!
It is like a person who encounters turbid water on the road, and although they have never seen it before, they also give rise to doubt, thinking, Is such water deep?
Or is it shallow?
This person has not seen it before, so why do they give rise to doubt?
Good man!
The so-called nirvÄá¹‡a is the cessation of suffering.
That which is not nirvÄá¹‡a is suffering.
All sentient beings have two kinds of views: the view of suffering and the view of non-suffering.

Suffering and non-suffering refer to hunger and thirst, cold and heat, anger and joy, illness and health, old age and youth, birth and death, bondage and liberation, separation from loved ones, and encountering those one dislikes.
When sentient beings see this, they immediately give rise to doubt, wondering if there will be a definitive separation from such suffering and distress.
Therefore, sentient beings give rise to doubt regarding nirvÄá¹‡a.
If you think that this person has never seen turbid water before, how can there be doubt?
This is not so.
Why is it so?
Because this person has seen it elsewhere before, therefore, in a place he has never been to, he gives rise to doubt again.
World-Honored One!
When this person first sees the shallow and deep places, he has already not given rise to doubt. Why does he give rise to doubt now?
The Buddha said:
Good man!
Because he has not practiced before, he gives rise to doubt.
Therefore, I say that because of incomprehension, there is doubt.
Bodhisattva Kasyapa addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
As the Buddha has said, doubt is precisely attachment, and attachment is precisely doubt.
To whom does this refer?
Good man!
It refers to those who have severed the roots of goodness.
Kasyapa said:
World-Honored One!
What kind of people are able to sever the roots of goodness?
Good man!
If there are those who are intelligent, wise, sharp, and able to discern well,

but who stay far away from good friends, do not listen to the true Dharma, do not contemplate well, and do not abide in accordance with the Dharma, such people are able to sever the roots of goodness.
Apart from these four things, they think to themselves:
'There are no objects to give.
Why is it so?
Giving is the relinquishing of wealth and goods. If giving has retribution, then one should always be poor.
Why is it so?
Because the result resembles the cause. Therefore, it is said there is no cause and no effect.
If one speaks thus of no cause and no effect, then this is called severing the roots of goodness.
He further thinks:

The giver, the receiver, and the wealth and goods, these three things are impermanent and do not remain. If they do not remain, how can one say this is the giver, the receiver, and the wealth and goods?
If there is no receiver, how can there be a result?
For this reason, there is no cause and no effect.
If one speaks thus of no cause and no effect, one should know that this person can sever the roots of goodness.
He further thinks:
'When the giver gives, there are five things given, and when the receiver receives, they may sometimes do good or do evil, but the giver also does not obtain the fruits of good or evil.
It is like the worldly law, where fruits are produced from seeds, and the fruits in turn produce seeds.
The cause is the giver and the fruit is the receiver, but the receiver cannot use these good or evil dharmas to make the giver obtain them. For this reason, there is no cause and no fruit.'
If one speaks in this way of no cause and no fruit, one should know that this person is able to sever the roots of goodness.
He further thinks:
'There are no objects of giving.
Why is it so?
The objects of giving are indeterminate.
If they are indeterminate, how can they obtain a good karmic retribution?
There are no fruits of good or evil, which are then indeterminate.

If the wealth is indeterminate, one should know that there are no fruits of good or evil retribution. Therefore, there is no giving, no cause, and no fruit.'ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
If one speaks thus of no cause and no effect, one should know that this person is able to sever wholesome roots.
He further thinks:
'The giver is the mind.
If it is the mind, it is invisible and unimpeded, not a form.
If it is not form, how can it be given?
Therefore, there is no giving, no cause, and no effect.'
If one speaks thus of no cause and no effect, one should know that this person is able to sever wholesome roots.
He further thinks:
'If the donor gives to Buddha images, heavenly images, or deceased parents, there is no recipient. If there is no recipient, there should be no karmic retribution.
If there is no karmic retribution, this is no cause. If there is no cause, this is no effect.'
If one speaks thus of no cause and no effect, one should know that this person is able to sever wholesome roots.
He further thinks:
'There is no father, no mother.
If you say that parents are the cause of sentient beings and give rise to sentient beings, it should be that they are constantly giving birth, without interruption.
Why is it so?
Because the cause always exists.
But they are not constantly giving birth, therefore you should know that there are no parents.'
He further thought like this:
'There is no father and no mother.
Why is it so?

If the body of sentient beings exists because of parents, one person should possess both male and female organs, but there is no one who possesses them, therefore you should know that sentient beings are not caused by parents.'
He further thought like this:
'Sentient beings are not born because of parents.
Why is it so?
The eyes see that sentient beings do not resemble their parents, in terms of body, color, mind, deportment, and behavior, therefore parents are not the cause of sentient beings.'
He further thought like this:
'In the entire world, there are four kinds of non-existence:
The first is called non-existence before birth, like when it is still a lump of clay, it has not yet become a usable vase.
Second, after being destroyed, it is called non-existence, like a broken vase, which is called non-existent.
Third, mutually non-existent in difference, like a cow not having a horse, and a horse not having a cow.
Fourth, ultimately called non-existence, like rabbit horns and turtle hair.
Sentient beings' parents are also like this, the same as these four non-existences.
If it is said that parents are the cause of sentient beings, when the parents die, the child does not necessarily die. Therefore, parents are not the cause of sentient beings.
He further thought:
If it is said that parents are the cause of sentient beings, then sentient beings should always be born due to parents.
However, there are also those born through transformation and moisture. Therefore, you should know that sentient beings are not born due to parents.
He further thought:
There are sentient beings who are not born and grow due to parents.
For example, a peacock becomes pregnant upon hearing the sound of thunder.
It is like the blue bird, which becomes pregnant by drinking the urine of the male bird.
It is like the myna bird, which becomes pregnant by seeing the male dancing.
When one has these thoughts, if one does not encounter a good spiritual friend, one should know that this person is able to sever good roots.
He further thought:
'In all worlds there are no fruits of good and evil.
Why is it so?
There are sentient beings who possess the ten wholesome dharmas, delight in giving, and diligently cultivate merits.
Such people also suffer from illnesses, die young, lose their wealth, and have much worry and suffering.
There are those who commit the ten evil deeds, are stingy, greedy, jealous, lazy, and do not cultivate any good;
yet their bodies are at ease, free from illness, they live long, have much wealth and treasure, and have no worries or sorrows.
Therefore, one should know that there are no fruits of good and evil.'
He further thought:
'I have also heard the sages say that some people who cultivate goodness often fall into the three evil paths after death;
some people who do evil are reborn in the human and heavenly realms after death;
therefore, one should know that there are no fruits of good and evil.'
He further thought:

'All sages have two kinds of teachings. Some say that killing brings good rewards, while others say that killing brings bad consequences. Therefore, one should know that the sages' teachings are not definite.
If the sages are not definite, how can I be definite?
Therefore, one should know that there are no fruits of good and evil.'
He further thought:
'In the entire world, there are no sages.
Why is it so?

If one says that sages should attain the right path, and all beings possess afflictions while practicing the right path, one should know that this person's right path and afflictions exist simultaneously. If they exist simultaneously, one should know that the right path cannot destroy the bonds.
If one cultivates the path without afflictions, what would this correct path accomplish?
Therefore, for one who possesses afflictions, the path cannot destroy them;
for one who does not possess afflictions, the path is useless.
Thus, one should know that there are no sages in the world.
He further thought:
'The twelve links of dependent origination, from ignorance as a condition for volitional formations up to birth as a condition for old age and death, are equally shared by all sentient beings.
The nature of the eightfold noble path is also equal, so when one person attains it, all should attain it;
when one person cultivates it, all should extinguish suffering.
Why is this?
Because of the equality of afflictions.
But now this is not the case, so one should know that there is no correct path.'
He further thought:
'The sages all have the same dharmas as ordinary people, namely eating, sleeping, being happy, laughing, being hungry, thirsty, cold, hot, sorrowful, and fearful.
If they do the same things as ordinary people, one should know that the sages have not attained the holy path;
if they have attained the holy path, they should have permanently severed such things.
If such things are not severed, one should know there is no path.'
He further thought like this:

'The sages have bodies and experience the five desires and pleasures, also scolding, beating others, being jealous, arrogant, experiencing suffering and happiness, and creating good and evil karma. For this reason, one knows there are no sages.
If there were a path, they should have severed these things, but these things are not severed, so one should know there is no path.'
He further thought like this:
'One who has great compassion is called a sage.
For what reasons is one called a sage?
Because of the path and conditions, they are called sages.
If the nature of the path is compassion, then it should have compassion for all sentient beings, not waiting to be cultivated before it can be attained.
If it has no compassion, why can sages, because of attaining the sage path, have compassion?
Therefore, you should know that there are no sages in the world.
He further thought:
'All four great elements are not born from causes. Sentient beings equally have the nature of the four great elements, not considering whether they should reach this side or not reach that side.
If there is a sage path, its nature should be like this.
But it is not so now, therefore you should know that there are no sages in the world.'
He further thought:
'If all sages have one nirvÄá¹‡a, then you should know that there are no sages.
Why is this?
Because it cannot be attained.
The principle of the eternally abiding Dharma cannot be attained, accepted, or abandoned.
If the nirvÄá¹‡a of the noble ones is many, then it is impermanent.
Why is this?
Because it is a countable dharma.
If nirvÄá¹‡a is one, when one person attains it, all should attain it.
If nirvÄá¹‡a is many, then it has boundaries. If it has boundaries, how can it be called permanent?
If someone says that the essence of nirvÄá¹‡a is one, but liberation is many, like an umbrella is one, but teeth and tongue are many,
this is not so.
Why is this?
Each attainment is not the attainment of all.
Because it has boundaries, it should be impermanent.ğŸ”½If it is impermanent, how can it be called nirvÄá¹‡a?
If nirvÄá¹‡a does not exist, who are the noble ones?
Therefore, you should know that there are no noble ones.
He further thought:
The path of the noble ones is not attained through conditions.
If the path of the noble ones is not attained through conditions, why do not all become noble ones?
If all people are not sages, then know that there are no sages and no path of sages.
He further thought:
The sages speak of right view, which has two causes and conditions:
First, hearing the Dharma from others; second, internally contemplating by oneself.
These two causes and conditions, if born from conditions, that from which they are born further arises from conditions. In this way, there is the fault of infinite regress.
If these two things are not born from conditions, why do all sentient beings not attain them?
When contemplating in this way, one can sever the roots of goodness.
Good man!
If there are sentient beings who deeply see in this way that there are no causes and no effects, then these people can sever the five faculties such as faith.
Good man!
Those who sever the roots of goodness are not inferior or dull people, nor are they in the heavens or the three evil destinies. Destroying the Saá¹…gha is also like this.
Bodhisattva KÄÅ›yapa addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
When will such a person be able to give rise to wholesome roots again?
The Buddha said:
Good man!
This person will give rise to wholesome roots again at two times: when first entering hell and when leaving hell.
Good man!
There are three kinds of wholesome: past, present, and future.
If it is past, its nature is already extinguished. Although the cause has ceased, the karmic retribution has not yet matured. Therefore, it is not called cutting off the past result.
Cutting off the causes of the three times is called cutting off.
Bodhisattva KÄÅ›yapa addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
If cutting off the causes of the three times is called cutting off wholesome roots,
then one who has cut off wholesome roots will have buddha-nature.
Is this buddha-nature past, present, or future? Or does it pervade the three times?
If it is past, how can it be called permanent?
Buddha-nature is also permanent. Therefore, you should know that it is not past.
If it is in the future, how can it be called permanent?
Why did the Buddha say that all sentient beings will definitely attain [enlightenment]?
If they will definitely attain it, why say it is cut off?
If it is in the present, how can it be permanent?
Why also say it can definitely be seen?
The TathÄgata also says that buddha-nature has six aspects:
permanent, true, real, good, pure, and visible.
If those who have cut off wholesome roots have buddha-nature, then they cannot be called those who have cut off wholesome roots.
If they do not have buddha-nature, why also say that all sentient beings have buddha-nature?
If it is said that buddha-nature is both existent and cut off, why did the TathÄgata also say it is permanent?
The Buddha said:
Good man!
The TathÄgata, the World-Honored One, for the sake of sentient beings, has four kinds of answers:
definite answers, analytical answers, answers according to the question, and inconclusive answers.
Good man!
What is a definitive answer?
If one asks whether unwholesome actions lead to wholesome fruits
or unwholesome fruits,
one should definitely answer that they lead to unwholesome fruits;
wholesomeness is also like this.
If one asks whether the TathÄgata is omniscient,
one should definitely answer that he is omniscient.
If one asks whether the Buddha's teachings are pure,
one should definitely answer that they are definitely pure.
If one asks whether the TathÄgata's disciples abide in accordance with the Dharma,
one should definitely answer that there are those who abide in accordance with the Dharma.
This is called a definitive answer.
What is an analytical answer?
As I have explained the teaching of the Four Noble Truths.
What are the four?
Suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.
What is the truth of suffering?
Because there are eight kinds of suffering, it is called the truth of suffering.
What is the truth of the origin [of suffering]?
Because the five aggregates are causes, it is called the truth of the origin [of suffering].
What is the truth of cessation?
Because greed, anger, and delusion are ultimately exhausted, it is called the truth of cessation.
What is the truth of the path?
Because of the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment, it is called the truth of the path.
This is called a discriminating answer.
What is an answer according to the question?
As I have said, all dharmas are impermanent.
There is also a question:
For what dharma did the TathÄgata say impermanence?
The answer is:
The TathÄgata spoke of impermanence for conditioned dharmas, and the same is true for non-self.
As I have said, all dharmas burn others.
There is also a question:
For what dharma did the TathÄgata say all burn?
The answer is:
The TathÄgata spoke of all burning for greed, anger, and delusion.
Good man!

The TathÄgata's ten powers, four fearlessnesses, great compassion, three establishments of mindfulness, ÅšÅ«raá¹ƒgama and other eighty koá¹­Ä«s of samÄdhi gates, thirty-two marks, eighty minor marks, five wisdom seals and other thirty-five thousand samÄdhi gates, vajra samÄdhi and other four thousand two hundred samÄdhi gates, and the immeasurable and boundless skillful means samÄdhisâ€”such dharmas are the Buddha's buddha-nature.
This buddha-nature has seven aspects:
permanence, self, bliss, purity, truth, reality, and goodness. This is called a differentiated answer.
Good son!
The buddha-nature of a bodhisattva in his final existence has six aspects:
permanence, purity, truth, reality, goodness, and partial manifestation. This is called a differentiated answer.

As you asked before, a person who has severed the roots of goodness has buddha-nature. This person also has the buddha-nature of the TathÄgata and also has the buddha-nature of the future body. These two buddha-natures are obstructed in the future, so they are called non-existent.
Because they will definitely be attained, they are called existent.
This is called an analytical answer.
The buddha-nature of the TathÄgata is neither past, nor present, nor future. The buddha-nature of the future body is present and future, because a little can be seen. It is called present.
Because it is not fully seen, it is called future.
When the TathÄgata has not yet attained supreme perfect enlightenment, the buddha-nature is a cause, and it is also past, present, and future.
The fruition is not so. Some are in the three time periods, some are not in the three time periods.
Because the buddha-nature of the future body bodhisattva is a cause, it is also past, present, and future. The fruition is also like this.
This is called an analytical answer.
The Buddha-nature of the bodhisattva in the ninth stage is of six kinds:
1. Eternal, 2. Good, 3. True, 4. Real, 5. Pure, 6. Visible.
Because the Buddha-nature is the cause, it is also the past, present, and future.
The effect is also like this.
This is called a discriminating answer.
The bodhisattva in the eighth stage down to the sixth stage has the Buddha-nature of five things:
1. True, 2. Real, 3. Pure, 4. Good, 5. Visible.
Because the Buddha-nature is the cause, it is also the past, present, and future, and the effect is also like this.
This is called a discriminating answer.
The bodhisattva in the fifth stage down to the first stage has the Buddha-nature of five things:
1. True, 2. Real, 3. Pure, 4. Visible, 5. Good and not good.
Good man!

These five kinds of Buddha-nature, six kinds of Buddha-nature, and seven kinds of Buddha-nature, because those who have severed wholesome roots will definitely attain them, it is said that they exist.
This is called a discriminating answer.
If someone says that those who have severed the roots of goodness definitely have buddha-nature or definitely do not have buddha-nature, this is called a neutral answer.
Bodhisattva Kasyapa said:
World-Honored One!
I have heard that not answering is called a neutral answer.
Why does the Tathagata now answer and call it a neutral answer?
Good man!
I also do not say that not answering is called a neutral answer.
Good man!
There are two kinds of neutral answers:
First, stopping; second, not being attached.
For this reason, it is called a neutral answer.
Bodhisattva Kasyapa addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
As the Buddha has said, how is it that the cause is also the past, present, and future,
And the effect is also the past, present, and future, but not the past, present, and future?
The Buddha said:ğŸ”½Good man!
Good man!
The five aggregates are of two kinds:
first, causes, and second, effects.
These causal five aggregates are past, present, and future.
These resultant five aggregates are also past, present, and future, but are also not past, present, and future.
Good man!
All ignorance, afflictions, and bonds are all buddha-nature.
Why is it so?
Because buddha-nature is the cause.
From ignorance, karmic formations, and all afflictions, one obtains the wholesome five aggregates, which is called buddha-nature.
From the wholesome five aggregates, one attains supreme, perfect enlightenment.
Therefore, I first explained in the sutra that the buddha-nature of sentient beings is like blood-mixed milk;

the blood is ignorance, karmic formations, and all afflictions, while the milk is the wholesome five aggregates.ğŸ”½Here is the text with the alignment mistakes fixed and the English translations updated to match the Sanskrit:ğŸ”½Good man!
Therefore I say that from the afflictions and the five wholesome aggregates, one attains supreme, perfect enlightenment.
Just as the bodies of sentient beings are all accomplished from semen and blood, so is buddha-nature.
SrotÄpannas and saká¹›dÄgÄmins who have severed a few afflictions, their buddha-nature is like milk.
AnÄgÄmins, their buddha-nature is like yogurt.
Arhats, they are like fresh butter.
From pratyekabuddhas up to the bodhisattvas of the tenth stage, they are like clarified butter.
The TathÄgata's buddha-nature is like the finest ghee.
Good man!
Because present afflictions create obstructions, they prevent sentient beings from being able to see it.
Just as on Fragrant Mountain there is the herb of forbearance, which not all cows can eat;
Buddha-nature is also like this.
This is called a discriminating answer.
Bodhisattva KÄÅ›yapa addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
If the five kinds, six kinds, and seven kinds of buddha-nature exist in the future, why is it said that a person who has severed wholesome roots has buddha-nature?
The Buddha said:
Good man!
Just as all sentient beings have past karma, and because of this karma, sentient beings in the present can receive the fruits of retribution,
there is future karma, which because it has not yet arisen, will never produce fruits. There are present afflictions.

If there were no afflictions, all sentient beings would clearly and presently see buddha-nature. Therefore, a person who has severed wholesome roots, because of the causes and conditions of present-world afflictions, is able to sever wholesome roots.
Because of the power and causes and conditions of future buddha-nature, wholesome roots are then produced.
KÄÅ›yapa said:
World-Honored One!
How can the future produce wholesome roots?
Good man!
It is just like a lamp or the sun, although they have not yet arisen, they are still able to destroy darkness.
The future birth can give rise to the future buddha-nature of sentient beings, it is also like this.
This is called a discriminating answer.
Bodhisattva Kasyapa addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
If it is said that the five aggregates are the buddha-nature, how can it be said that the buddha-nature of sentient beings is neither internal nor external?
The Buddha said:
Good man!
For what reason do you have such a misunderstanding?
Didn't I previously say that the buddha-nature of sentient beings is the middle way?
Kasyapa said:
World-Honored One!
I truly do not misunderstand, but because sentient beings cannot understand this middle way, I therefore ask about it.
Good man!
Sentient beings' lack of understanding is precisely the middle way.
Sometimes there is understanding, sometimes there is lack of understanding.
Good man!
I speak of the buddha-nature as neither internal nor external in order to help sentient beings gain understanding.
Why is it so?
Ordinary beings may say that buddha-nature abides within the five aggregates, like fruit in a container;
or they may say that it exists apart from the aggregates, like empty space;
Therefore, the TathÄgata speaks of the middle way.
The buddha-nature of sentient beings is neither the six sense faculties within nor the six sense objects without. It is called the middle way because of the combination of the inner and outer.
Therefore, the TathÄgata proclaims that buddha-nature is precisely the middle way, neither within nor without, and is therefore called the middle way.
This is called a discriminating answer.
Furthermore, good man!
What is meant by neither within nor without?
Good man!
Some say that buddha-nature is precisely the non-Buddhist path.
Why is it so?

Because bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, over innumerable eons, within the non-Buddhist path, cut off all afflictions, subdue their minds, and teach and transform sentient beings, and only then attain supreme, perfect enlightenment. Therefore, buddha-nature is precisely the non-Buddhist path.
Some say that buddha-nature is precisely the inner path.
Why is it so?

Although bodhisattvas cultivate the outer path for immeasurable eons, if they are apart from the inner path, they will not be able to attain supreme perfect enlightenment. Therefore, buddha-nature is precisely the inner path.
Therefore, the TathÄgata blocks these two extremes and says that buddha-nature is neither internal nor external, and is also called internal and external. This is called the middle way.
This is called a discriminating answer.
Furthermore, good man!
Some say that buddha-nature is precisely the vajra body of the TathÄgata, the thirty-two marks, and the eighty minor marks.
Why is it so?
Because it is not false or deceptive.
Some say that buddha-nature is precisely the ten powers, the four forms of fearlessness, great compassion, the three forms of mindfulness, and all samÄdhis such as the Å›Å«raá¹ƒgama.
Why is it so?
Because the vajra body, the thirty-two marks, and the eighty minor marks arise from these samÄdhis.
Therefore, the TathÄgata rejects these two extremes and says that buddha-nature is neither internal nor external, and is also called internal and external. This is called the middle way.
This is called a discriminating answer.
Furthermore, good man!
Some say that buddha-nature is precisely the good thoughts within.
Why is it so?
Because apart from good thoughts, one cannot attain supreme perfect enlightenment, therefore buddha-nature is precisely the good thoughts within.
Some say that buddha-nature is precisely the Dharma heard from others.
Why is it so?

Because by hearing the Dharma from others, one can have good thoughts within. If one does not hear the Dharma, then there are no thoughts. Therefore buddha-nature is precisely the Dharma heard from others.
Therefore, the TathÄgata rejects these two extremes and says that buddha-nature is neither internal nor external, and is also called internal and external. This is called the middle way.
Furthermore, good man!

Some say the Buddha-nature is external, referring to the perfection of giving, and that from the perfection of giving one attains supreme perfect enlightenment. Therefore, it is said that the perfection of giving is the Buddha-nature.
Some say the Buddha-nature is internal, referring to the five perfections.
Why is it so?
Apart from these five things, one should know that there is no cause or effect of the Buddha-nature. Therefore, it is said that the five perfections are the Buddha-nature.
Therefore, the TathÄgata refutes these two extremes and says that the Buddha-nature is neither internal nor external, but both internal and external. This is called the middle way.
Furthermore, good man!
Some say the Buddha-nature is internal, like the precious pearl on the forehead of a strong man.
Why is it so?
Because of permanence, bliss, self, and purity, like a precious pearl, therefore it is said that the Buddha-nature is internal.
Some say the Buddha-nature is external, like a poor person's treasure trove.
Why is it so?
Because it is seen through skillful means.
Buddha-nature is also like this. It is outside of sentient beings, but through skillful means, one can see it.
Therefore, the TathÄgata refutes these two extremes and says that buddha-nature is neither internal nor external, but also internal and external. This is called the middle way.
Good man!
The buddha-nature of sentient beings is neither existent nor nonexistent.
Why is it so?
Although buddha-nature exists, it is not like empty space.
Why is it so?
Although worldly empty space cannot be seen through immeasurable skillful means,
buddha-nature can be seen. Therefore, although it exists, it is not like empty space.
Although buddha-nature does not exist, it is not the same as a rabbit's horns.
Why is it so?
Although rabbit horns cannot be produced through immeasurable skillful means,
buddha-nature can be produced. Therefore, although it does not exist, it is not the same as a rabbit's horns.
Therefore, buddha-nature is neither existent nor nonexistent, but also existent and nonexistent.
What is meant by existence?
All of them have it. These sentient beings are not cut off or extinguished, just like the flame of a lamp, until they attain supreme perfect enlightenment. Therefore, it is called existence.
What is called nonexistence?
All sentient beings do not presently have all the qualities of a buddha, permanence, bliss, self, and purity. Therefore, it is called nonexistence.
Because existence and nonexistence are combined, it is the middle way. Therefore, the Buddha said that the buddha-nature of sentient beings is neither existent nor nonexistent.
Good son!
If someone asks, 'In this seed, is there a fruit or not?'
One should definitely answer, 'It is both existent and nonexistent.'
Why is it so?
Because apart from the seed, it cannot produce a fruit, it is called existent.
Because the seed has not yet sprouted, it is called nonexistent.
For this reason, it is both existent and nonexistent.
Why is it so?
Because the time is different, but the essence is the same.
The Buddha-nature of sentient beings is also like this. If one says that apart from sentient beings there is a separate Buddha-nature, this is not correct.
Why is it so?
Sentient beings are precisely the Buddha-nature, and the Buddha-nature is precisely sentient beings;
It is just that there are differences in purity and impurity at different times.
Good man!
If someone asks, Can the seed produce the fruit? Can the fruit produce the seed?
One should definitely answer, It both produces and does not produce.
World-Honored One!
How is it that worldly people say that milk contains curd?
Good man!
If someone says that milk contains curd, this is called attachment.
If one says there is no curd, this is called falsehood.
Apart from these two things, one should definitely say that it both exists and does not exist.
Why is it called existent?
Because curd arises from milk, the cause is milk and the effect is curd, this is called existent.
Why is it called non-existent?
The color and taste are different, and their uses are not the same. For a fever one takes milk, for a cold one takes curd. Milk produces cold illnesses, curd produces hot illnesses.
Good man!
If you say that milk contains the nature of curd, then milk is curd, and curd is milk. Their nature is the same.
For what reason does milk come out first, and curd does not come out first?
If there is a reason, why do all worldly people not speak of it?
If there is no reason, why does curd not come out first?
If curd does not come out first, who makes the sequence - milk, curd, fresh butter, clarified butter, and ghee?
Therefore, know that curd, first non-existent, now existent. If first non-existent, now existent, it is a impermanent dharma.
Good man!
If there is someone who says: Milk has the nature of curd, and can produce curd. Water does not have the nature of curd, therefore it does not produce curd. This reasoning is not so.
Why is it so?
Water and grass also have the nature of milk and curd.
Why is this?
Because of water and grass, milk and curd come out.
If it is said that milk definitely has the nature of curd, while water and grass do not, this is called false.
Why is this?
Because the mind is not equal, it is said to be false.
Good man!
If it is said that milk definitely has the nature of curd, then curd should also definitely have the nature of milk. For what reason does milk produce curd, but curd does not produce milk?
If there is no reason, then one should know that curd was originally non-existent but now exists.
Therefore, the wise should say that milk neither has the nature of curd nor is devoid of the nature of curd.
Good man!
Therefore, the TathÄgata said in this sÅ«tra, 'All sentient beings definitely have buddha-nature,' which is called attachment;
if there is no buddha-nature, this is called false.
The wise should say that the buddha-nature of sentient beings is both existent and non-existent.
Good man!
Four things come together to produce eye-consciousness.
What are the four?
Eye, form, light, and desire.
The nature of eye-consciousness is neither eye, nor form, nor light, nor desire, but arises from the combination of these.
Thus, eye-consciousness was non-existent before and now exists, and after existing, it will again become non-existent.
Therefore, you should know that it has no inherent nature. The nature of curd in milk is also like this.
If someone says that water has no nature of curd and therefore does not produce curd, and therefore the nature of curd definitely exists in milk,

Why is it so?
Good man!
The causes of all dharmas are different, and the results are also different. It is not that one cause produces all results, nor that all results come from one cause.
Good man!
For example, the four things produce eye-consciousness, and one cannot say that from these four things, ear-consciousness should be produced.
Good man!
Apart from skillful means, one cannot obtain curd from milk or ghee from curd. This is not possible without skillful means.
Good man!
The wise cannot see that apart from skillful means, curd can be obtained from milk, and that ghee can be obtained in the same way without skillful means.
Good man!
Therefore, I say in this sutra that because of arising, dharmas exist; because of cessation, dharmas do not exist.
Good man!
It is like how salt has a salty nature and can make what is not salty become salty.

It is obtained because of other conditions, and thus it becomes salty.
If it is said that all non-salty things have a salty nature, but it is subtle and unknown, and thus salt can make it salty because of this subtle nature,

It is like a seed having its own four great elements, relying on the external four great elements to grow sprouts, stems, branches, and leaves. Salt's nature is also like this. This reasoning is incorrect.

If non-salty things already have the nature of salt, then salt should also have a subtle non-salty nature.
If this salt has these two natures, then for what reason, apart from non-salty things, cannot it be used alone?
Therefore, it is known that salt originally has no two natures.
Like salt, all non-salty things are also like this.
